Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8 - Not what I expected....
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I picked up this portable video camcorder a few days ago from BestBuy, and I really wanted to like it since it was the highest rated among its competitors on Cnet.  Shooting on this thing was a breeze, and it looks good on the small 2" screen, clear and sharp. ( i shot on 720p 60fps, image stabalizer on)  However as I uploaded the .mov files into my computer and watched them,  the screen shakiness was horrid. There was micro shakes in the shots where I tried to be as still as possible, and even worse on shots where I tried to do smooth pans across a street.  I really wanted to puke....Never had I felt this dizzy since watching Cloverfield in the theatres.  The image wasn't as hd sharp as I thought. Not even close. But Cnet did warn us that these devices aren't true HD's like the cameras that are hundreds of dollars more. It's only slightly better than standard quality.  My biggest problem was the screen shakiness.....I've shot concerts and videos on my point-and-shoot Canon Powershot Camera before...where I was holding the camera up with one hand for an hour....and the playback on those videos were fine....But I couldn't even watch a 10 second clip I shot on the Kodak Zi8.....the stabalization is horrid...I even tried to resize the clip to a smaller 320x480'ish  size to see if the shakiness was better but it was still there. I made about 100 short clips and on almost half of them the recording play back stuttered slightly where it looked like it was playing at 23 fps instead of 60fps....I was very surprised by this.  You are better off making standard quality videos on your point and shoot camera....the sound recording and picture quality is much better on those than this HD Kodak camcorder... =(  Yeah the sound is really bad on the Kodak Zi8 too....  To think the Flip Ultra's and Mino HD's don't even have Image stabalizer.....I could only imagine those handheld camcorders might be even worse.....I hope this helps......I'm going to try returning this to Best Buy.....

Reviews.Title: Listen to the Bad Reviews
Reviews.Author: Mayakah Hunter
Reviews.Content: There is a debate in the reviews as to whether or not this camera has lines that ruin the picture quality.  I am telling you it does.  I had the updated version and followed the instruction to download the updated software which I already had just incase.  It doesn't work.  Poor picture quality is the bottom line.  Any good review on this one must be from Kodak.  I returnd through Amazon and got the Lumix.  It's great!

Reviews.Title: Audio is FIXED with new firmware 1.03!
Reviews.Author: Razor Ammo
Reviews.Content: Like everyone else, I also had the high pitch whine in all my audio with the internal mic. I almost sold it because of my disappointment. I even bought a cheap-ebay Sony external mic, which worked really well, but was a hassle to carry with the Zi8. Just as I was ready to sell it, I stumbled upon KodakConnect!High pitch whine?... Not anymore! It's fixed with the new firmware(1.03)!Just Google KodakConnect, twitter or email them your request and you'll get a reply within a few days. Not sure if it's proper to post emails here - so contact them, and they will contact you. I'm not sure why they haven't gone public with this firmware fix yet...I won't repeat all of the great things about this that everyone here has said, but for my fixed internal mic, it's 1 step closer to perfection!Thank you Kodak! Bring on Zi9!!!

Reviews.Title: Great choice for external mic and macro mode
Reviews.Author: Marlon R.
Reviews.Content: I got this camera in early 2011 after a ton of research and near sleepless nights reading reviews & watching video. Color me obsessed. The Zi8 is not perfect, but for the money and features it will deliver what you need.  It seems to have gone up in price since I bought, maybe Kodak realized they had a winner on their hands.What I like:compact design and varied ability to shoot standard def, and 3 different HD modes (720, 720/60fps for fast action, and 1080). The best features about this camera are without a doubt the external mic input and the amazing macro mode. This camera really excels in macro mode (that means super close focus for you newbies). There is a switch that allows you to go from normal focus to close up mode, and it works while you are shooting so you can go back & forth. There will be a slight "click" in your recordings if you do this, but its not a big bother. The close-up image quality is really quite astounding for a camera in this price range.The external mic input is an absolute must. I will also say that this unit has a very good onboard mic despite some of the reviews. Its ahead of most of the other digicams with regard to built-in mics that I researched. That was key in my buying decision. the onboard mic will do the job for you. But for really professional "amateur" video, you really should take advantage of the external mic. There are many recommendations about mics, but I can tell you even my cheap 8-year old Logitech computer mic works great & is noise free. I've recorded speech and music with it and it sounds great.For those that don't know, the issue with onboard mics on cameras: they pick up motor noise from the camera running, especially when the auto-focus or zoom engages. Use of an external mic, even a cheap one, completely eliminates this hassle. It also allows you to move the mic closer to the subject. This is great for YouTube videos or anyone doing product reviews. If there is just one thing you can do to improve your amateur videos, it's use of external mic.I also like the display and the camera is fairly easy to navigate the menus. It shoots & records video quickly, no lag-time in playback or turning on or off.Software-the included software is surprisingly good. Has some editing feature and color correction too that is really nice even though I use separate more professional programs for that.What I don't like:Its a little clunky moving around the menus and the tiny joystick is just okay. Not sure if buttons would be better, but its got buttons too. You can probably figure out this camera without the instruction manual, Kodak makes straightforward stuff where this is concerned. But do read the instructions (for example, you'll find that the brightness setting in the camera does nothing for the shooting, its just for the LCD as briefly explained in the instructions. There would be no way to know this otherwise & I wasted a good deal of time shooting comparison videos on different brightness settings for nothing!) The instructions could be more detailed, but they are better than most instructions that come with electronics these days. It seems companies these days have short-changed their users by shortening up the instructions, but print them in four additional languages you can't read in the same booklet.The camera has an auto-shutoff which happens every five minutes or so if untouched. This can be annoying when its setup on a tripod ready to shoot, but hey it saves battery life.The LCD is pretty good but I still find it small and you have to really get up on it to see the video. For the money its fine, but this may bother some people.Don't buy this camera thinking you'll get great still photos despite the higher MP rating. The still shots are okay, but would guess most high-end smartphones will take better stills and there is no flash. This is not a replacement for a good point-and-shoot camera for stills, but it would do the job for a quick shot here & there when you can't carry your bigger camera.It would have been nice if Kodak put a light on the front of the camera so you knew it was recording. Instead, there is just a "beep" to let you know its rolling if you aren't able to see the LCD (like if its on a tripod and you're filming yourself).There is no flash on this unit.Tips:Get some cheap spare batteries that are compatible, and get a remote & AC adapter. Amazon is great for this. I have two batteries and the adapter & have never run out of juice. The AC adapter is crucial because while it really won't charge the battery, it will run your camera on AC while you are shooting video and saves your battery. I have the remote also, another inexpensive purchase, its not labeled that well but it does work and will save you from having to get up and touch the camera again.Make sure you have enough light for shooting indoors and research "3 point lighting" on YouTube or wherever. Its a simple technique and can make your indoor videos really pop. I have shot many hours of video before I found out about this technique.All in all:Good value, good images, true HD with options, nice mic input and great macro mode. Good for normal shooting and fast action. Onboard mic is good enough but ext mic option way better. A little clunky getting around the menus and user controls but the finished product is really good. At the time of my purchase there was no equal camera with these features in the price range.Another winner from Kodak!

Reviews.Title: No longer good value for the money... external mic jack is very noisy
Reviews.Author: Marc Beneteau

} } } Length:: 2:44 MinsI paid about $100 for a refurbished model. This is quite a good price for what you get (good performance including good internal mic) but at $150 I would look either to a cheaper Flipcam or else to a higher-end AVCHD camera (in the end I replaced it with a used Canon Vixia HF10 at $200). Reason being, I shoot professional web video and I found the nighttime white balance terrible (and I could not figure out how to correct it) and the external mic jack was VERY noisy regardless of the input source.Another reviewer states that he used this camera with an Audio Technica ATR-3350 Lavalier mic, I tried this and it didn't work well, I actually think reviewer is incorrect as this is a low-output mic which requires a very high external mic gain on the camera which makes a very poor circuit design even worse. The internal mic was much better then the ATR-3350 (at a distance of about 6 feet) and particularly with Audacity noise reduction (through Sony Vegas) it was quite good.So in summary if your purpose is quick promotional video for the web (like at 640x480 or 640x360) its fine but if you want professional-quality video it won't cut it.Another very annoying thing was that it only comes with a 128MB SDHC Card so you will need to budget another $10-25 for an upgrade.I believe that this camera has been replaced by the Kodak Zi10 Play Touch ($124 best price) however this is a slightly inferior camera so not recommended for this purpose either.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Clarity for a portable HD Video/Camera
Reviews.Author: B. Family

} } } Length:: 0:17 MinsI wanted to create a video review for those of you interested in seeing real time how this camera performs. My experience is amazing and the clarity is amazing! While in bright conditions the glare on monitor is a little more difficult to see. It is portable and lightweight for meeting nearly all of your needs. I viewed my videos on my HD Flat Panel TV and was very impressed. I was also impressed by simply viewing them by plugging in the Zi8 Kodak into computers outlet. The negative part of the camera/video is the fluttering affect- even when image stabilization is turned on. I notice this more as a result of rapid movement from side to side and zooming in. The conditions are a April evening in South Florida.I hope that you are pleased with my review and find it informative in making your decisionNOTE: I WILL ATTEMPT TO UPLOAD A SMALLER VIDEO FILE AS THE ONE I HAD WAS TO LARGE

Reviews.Title: Really exceeded my expectations
Reviews.Author: amznuser34
Reviews.Content: Ive tried other 'mini' camcorders before and could never find one that could deliver outstanding picture quality to compliment its convenient small size.  With my Disney World vacation fast approaching, I started looking for a new camcorder late last month to replace my Cannon Hi8 digital.  After doing some research, I had narrowed it down to the Sony Bloggie Touch and this Kodak zi8.  I finally decided to go with the zi8 and could not be more pleased with it.  Ironically, my parents were about to leave for their own Disney vacation and after seeing my new camera, wanted me to order one for them.  I was very curious to see how this camera would perform and when they returned this past week I was very pleasantly surprised.I used the HDMI cable that was included with the camera to connect it to our 42 inch LG HDTV.  Right from the first moments of playback that I watched, the camera had already exceeded my expectations of it.  Video taken in the daylight outdoors was virtually flawless, other than some quick auto focus issues but they had more to do with how the person operating the camera was holding/moving it around.  I knew going in that it does not perform as well in lower light setting but if more of the lighting is on the subject and not the operator, then it still produces great quality video.  Even nighttime fireworks shows came out great as long as the camera is kept very still.  NOTE:  The recording mode 720p @ 60 frames/second shot the best video quality.The audio quality also impressed me with all sounds and voices being picked up very clearly and no noise from the cameras operation was heard at all upon playback.  I paired the camera with a Transcend 16 GB Class 6 (TS16GSDHC6E) memory card and the (Kodak 1736933) silicone sleeve.  Now I'm looking forward to using it on my trip also.I would highly recommend this camera to someone looking for a 'pocket' sized camera that can deliver HD quality recordings, without having to purchase a high end camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent video camera
Reviews.Author: gadget guy
Reviews.Content: This camera is excellent, without question. If you've been the video person for all your events through the years, do NOT look any further than the Zi8. It has everything you need to be a pro-am videographer. The biggest notable feature inclusions in this camera is independent memory cards and an external mic jack. These two features alone make this very reasonably priced camera worth the price of admission. I can't stress enough how important the external mic jack is. Drop every other cool feature you may be tempted by with the other cams, in favor of this feature. ESPECIALLY if you plan on using this for business presentations, band gigs, or higher end video shoots. You may think you'll never need it but trust me, if and when you do you'll know why the external mic jack is so great. The picture quality, in my opinion, beats ALL of the other offerings in this category- be it full light AND low light. I could add a video to my review but there's a ton of examples out there on video hosting sites to see for yourself. It becomes obvious after you start comparing picture qualities. Also do a search for mic comparisons with the Zi8 and hear for yourself why it's so huge that Kodak included the capability to use external mics.Out of the box, I needed no instructions to get the battery charging. Easy. The only time I cracked the rather modest manual is for a couple of navigational how-to's, as well as getting out the USB arm and hooking it up to the PC. It's worth reading through the manual as well- a short no nonsense read that will help. All in all, it's a really easy camera to operate. Don't fret over the LCD screen size either. I wear glasses and I STILL hoped like heck it would be big enough for me. I hate that screens are so small now. The LCD size is perfectly fine. I have no problems and I'm picky.The software has gotten slammed a bunch so I'll touch on it. It's basic. Those of you who don't do much editing will like it. Those of you who do may never open it up, once installed. It had an immediate update once installed, so of course I did it with no problems. I'll mention that if it wasn't part of the older versions, this newest one has the ability to render to MP4 and AVI when you publish to your computer- an option within the software. That seems like a good attempt on Kodaks part to resolve complaints about .MOV files locking you in without using third party converters. Re-rendering to different formats is just a part of digital life and if you want to get in this game you're gonna have to get savvy about the process. If it's not your cup of tea, stick with analog tape cameras and dump them out to dvd, or get a dvd cam. This type of camera has so much going for it that it's very much worth the learning curve of file management. Once you do it some, you get the hang of it and all the implications of resolution choices and such. It's not that hard for the computer/software inclinded. In the end, you'll either find Kodaks editing software enough, or you'll be relying on better software. Frankly, I found the editing preview playback to be glitchy and not really useable for serious editing. There are some settings to tweak though, such as accelerators within the program, that could help that. I didn't try, as I use another editor. The software should also be tweaked to include much more email choices for sending files, such as gmail, hotmail, etc. It only picked up on outlook and outlook express on my laptop. I haven't used those accounts in years. I believe it'll pick up on AOL too, but I haven't used THAT in even more years.Really, what more could you ask for? Great picture quality, portability, memory card sizes of your choosing, separate batteries so you can keep filming, a universal tripod mount, external mic jack, all the cables included, and editing software. What's the ONE thing I wish this camera had, out of the box? A lense cover- just as simple as that. It should have one. But this is one hell of a package for the average user and even the more advanced user. I was on the fence between the Zi8 and a toshiba camileo S20 because of some features it has to offer. I am so, so glad I chose the Zi8 instead. I gave flips a short consideration too, but there's no comparison to the Zi8. This Kodak has it all over them. I recommend the Kodak Zi8 highly. I'm planning some pretty high end shoots with this thing and I have no doubt it will handle it. Grab one while you can!

Reviews.Title: Great portable HD Camera
Reviews.Author: Adamtron
Reviews.Content: I'm really happy with the Kodak Zi8.  I bought it from Amazon for about $99 which I thought was a great price.  I took it to my birthday party at a night club.  It was able to take great HD video, even in the low lighting and loud music conditions of the club.  In situations where you don't want to bring a large video cam with you, this works great.  You can put it in your pocket and take it anywhere.  Also, I think friends/family are less intimidated by a smaller camera and more willing to have fun then if you had a large camera on them.  The only issue I had was that it comes with only 128 mb of memory.  You can only take about 10 seconds (yes seconds!) of video with the built in memory.  I had to run to Best Buy to get a memory card.  With a 16GB card you can record about 2.5 hours of video which is good.  You can also get a 32GB if you plan to record more.  I like the fact that it creates a ".mov" file which you can easily copy/paste from the device to your PC and edit in whichever program you want.  Overall I'm very satisfied with this product.

Reviews.Title: As good as they describe
Reviews.Author: booklover
Reviews.Content: I'll make it a short story: Needed an affordable camera with an external mic. Kodak is the only one, so I gave it a try.  (I own the Flip, but it doesn't have external mic option.) The quality of the video and sound with the external mic is amazing. If you're doing any filming where you have to pick up group conversation, this camera is the best. BTW, I also used the Bower wide angle magnetic lens and a really inexpensive omnidirectional mic from Radio Shack. I loved my Flip, but this Kodak does them one better.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Pocket Camcorder
Reviews.Author: Yug
Reviews.Content: I have been using Zi8 for the past 3 months and I am very happy with the product. The HD video recording quality is really good.The camcorder boots up in 2 secs because of which you will never miss a shot you want to capture.I also have a dedicated Sony HD Handy Cam which I used only twice in the last one year because of the portability issue.After getting this I use it so often,you can just put it in your pocket and take wherever you want. The factors that made me buy this over the Flip or Kodak Playsport are the 1080P feature,option for external mic and some sample videos on youtube showing the video comparisons between various pocket camcorders.

Reviews.Title: Great camera if you want something easy to use
Reviews.Author: H. Wang "nycmode"
Reviews.Content: In the interest of full disclosure, I purchased this camera for my father as a gift.  The reason being, my father is real big on shooting home videos and has been trying (ever slowly) to enter the digital age.  He has used the video function on his digital point and shoot cameras, but I figured the Kodak would be a simple and easy way to help him transition into digital home movies.I'm basing this review on my dad's experience (which is in short, someone who doesn't feel extremely comfortable with technology, but wants to get into it more).He really enjoyed using the camera thanks to its easy to use interface.  The instruction manual is pretty slim, and there is a reason for that.  It literally is a point and shoot video camera, much like the flip cam.  But what made me buy this one was the fact that it came with an included HDMI cable and an SD HC slot.  While the flip is all about internal memory, the Kodak only has a small amount of that built in.  It's more of an SD HC card video camera, so please keep that in mind before purchasing this camera.  If you're looking to shoot only on internal memory, this camera isn't for you.As I mentioned, the interface is simple and easy to figure out.  The picture quality of the camera is surprisingly good.  His first video was shot on 720p and when I hooked up the camera to my HDTV the image looked pretty decent.  Shooting on 1080 produced a surprisingly crisp and clear picture, which to be honest I wasn't totally expecting as I bought a Kodak camera at a relatively low price.  However, this camera definitely surprised me.  I did not use an external mic so I am unable to describe it here, however, from a pure point and shoot perspective, my dad loved the camera.  Even in low lighting conditions I found that the camera produced some pretty sharp images.  Impressive.My only gripe is that the camera battery needs to be charged with the entire camera itself.  There is no stand alone battery charger included with the camera (which is a pain if my dad say, wanted to charge one battery while using the camera with another).Bottom line:I like:1. Great budget friendly camera2. Not intimidating to use, and great for even tech noobs3. Nice big screen on the camera itself for easy viewing4. Has SD HC slot5. Includes HDMI cable for cameraI don't like:1. No battery charger included (i.e. have to charge battery w/camera cable)2. No real internal memory3. Seems a bit light/cheaply made, but that's just nitpickingAll in all, I still recommend this product to anyone who's looking for a pretty good camera for a good price.  This one fits the bill just fine.

Reviews.Title: Review from a company job use perspective
Reviews.Author: Frank B "Frank"
Reviews.Content: I use this camera for my company blog website. It does a great job in fair to good light situations which covers what trade shows and interviews I require it for. However in low lighting situations, it is unusable. Example would be a low light or candlelight restaurant or museum/aquarium. If Kodak were to add a flash and zoom to this camera and increase the 5mp to 10mp, it would be perfect. It takes decent 5mp pics and the video choices are fine for uploading to youtube and facebook. If you want better quality snapshots with higher resolution, carry a better camera with that capability as I do for my job. It has a sleek look and feels good in your hand. I use a tripod for video because you will need to move very slow/steady when videoing by hand. I also use a 16gb high end card for video editing. I like the usb direct connect from the camera. I purchased 3 extra batteries and a quick charger for the amount of use for my job. The other item I do not like is the internal microphone. I had to purchase a splitter and two external mics, one for my interviewing and one for the perspective interviewing client. I have had a lot of compliments and questions as passers by see the Zi8 being used. For the price it does the job for my use without buying a high cost, high end video camera. I recommend a good wireless mic if using it from a 15ft-20ft plus activity. Finally, close-up shots and close-up video clarity needs to be improved. All close-ups are fuzzy. I stay back about 1ft so everything stays in focus. I read the reviews of the new Kodak Playtouch since it has a zoom, but the reviews on the videos and the zoom were not good. I will await the next Kodak upgrade improvement and reviews. I realize I am trying to do a professional job with a semi-professional camera, but with department budget economics, I needed to find the best product to do a quality job at a decent lower cost. Based on all these pros and cons, I gave the camera 4 stars.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, Great Video, Great Value
Reviews.Author: Timothy B. Chastain "Tim C"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera instead of a FLIP because it was a better value and because the memory is "unlimited" (based on SD card).  It works easily and perfectly.  Very user friendly and takes great video.  The sound quality is more than adequate and can be used with an external mic as well.  The features of the camera are more than enough for our purposes.  You can easily download video into any computer with a USB port or SD card reader seeing that the camera uses both!  Very convenient and as said easy to use!  You will love this HD Video Camera!

Reviews.Title: The Best Camcorder you can get for personal or business use without spending a fortune!
Reviews.Author: Falk Adventures
Reviews.Content: // To view this video download Flash Player (version 9.0.115 or higher)'); } } catch(err) { fp_resizePlayerSpace('cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3', 0, 0); } return false; } function _cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3loadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { var swfLocation = "http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/01/am3/20120510035744301/AMPlayer._V148501545_.swf"; } cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3loadSwf_Core(swfLocation, swfWidth, swfHeight, flashVersion, bgColor, swfParams, flashParams, embedAttributes); return false; } function cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3loadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { return _cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3loadSwf(movieID, playerVersion); var cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay = document.getElementById('cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplayImageId'); if (cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay) { cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay.onmouseover = function() { cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay.src = "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/81XFR-0S5rS._SX320_PHcustomer-video-vignette_PIvideo-reviews-bottom,BottomLeft,0,43_OU01_PIcustomer-video-play-active,BottomLeft,130,-12_CR0,0,0,0_.png"; } cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay.onmouseout = function() { cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay.src = "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/81XFR-0S5rS._SX320_PHcustomer-video-vignette_PIvideo-reviews-bottom,BottomLeft,0,43_OU01_PIcustomer-video-play,BottomLeft,130,-12_CR0,0,0,0_.png"; } var node = cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3preplay.parentNode; var cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3currentClick = node.onclick; node.onclick = function () { var head = document.getElementsByTagName("head"); if (head[0]) { var logTag = document.createElement('script'); logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3currentClick) { return cv_mo3PZW5U33251M3currentClick(); } } } Length:: 3:29 MinsLet me start off this review by saying that I absolutely love this camera!I thought that the video we posted here would be a good choice because of the different lighting variations. We also didn't use the lavalier microphone so you can hear what the normal mic pics up and filmed this all by hand without the use of a tripod.We're an international adventure travel company, and we needed something that we could bring on our trips.Our Wish List:- A camera that was small and light weight for travel.- A camera that had an external mic plug-in.- Something relatively inexpensive.- With fantastic picture quality- A long battery life- Records in a file that is easy to editAfter some exhaustive research we found that the Zi8 was our best option and we "almost" got everything on our "Wish List."Small/ CompactPro: The camera is very small and light weight. It's about the size of my cell phone and perfect for throwing in our bags while trekking some jungle trails.Cons: NoneExternal Mic Plug-inPro: This camera has it! We use the Audio Technica ATR-3350 Lavalier Omnidirectional Condenser Microphone and it works perfectly!Cons: I'm glad the camera has an external mic plug-in because the regular camera mic is not all that fantastic. It works and sounds OK, but it's just not spectacular. Beyond probably 4 feet from the camera, the sound becomes muffled.InexpensivePro: Roughly $150!!! We're pretty active on our trips with hiking, rafting, kayaking, etc.. so the potential for damage is there. We wanted to get a camera that if damaged we wouldn't spend a whole lot of time crying over it.Picture QualityPro: This camera shoots in HD. We shoot all of our videos in 720p and the picture quality has met our expectations.Cons: The camera does get kind of temperamental in low light situations, but this really hasn't been much of a problem.Battery LifePro: At least it has one.Cons: It doesn't last very long. While shooting in 720p with image stabilization turned off we get roughly an 1 hr. 30 min - 2 hr.'s of film. I wish it was longerEditingPro: It does have editing software that is built into the camera and it is very basic. Probably good enough for family videos.Cons: This camera records only in .mov files. If your looking to do some real editing, and you have a PC, Good luck to you. We searched for a good program to edit these videos on our PC's with no luck. It's possible, but just not very easy. We ended up just buying some Mac's and editing is a breeze! Imovie loves .mov files.Here are a couple of other little things we learned about the camera.Image Stabilization- the camera comes with image stabilization. We have ran many tests and have found no difference with having it on or off. If your recording while walking with this in your hands, while watching the video on playback make sure you have a barf bag available. You're in for a bumpy ride.We ended up purchasing some extra equipment which has proved to be very valuable.The Audio Technica ATR-3350 Lavalier Omnidirectional Condenser Microphone has proven to be a valuable asset while conducting interviews or when in a noisy jungle and we want our voices to actually be heard.The AZDEN CAM-3 On-Camcorder Mini Audio Mixer has been valuable when wanting to hook up multiple microphones at one time.The Tekkeon TekCharge MP1800 has been useful in extending the battery life. Instead of around 2 hours of film time, we can now get about 5 hours on one charge.The XShot Camera Extender - Black (XS2379) is a great hand held tool which allows you to record yourself without having to set up the full tri-pod. The XShot also seems to steady the camera a bit while walking and filming yourself.A Tripod. You're going to need one. This camera will screw onto any standard tripod stand.If you want to see some more videos that were filmed using this camera just go to FalkAdventures.com and look in the blog section.Overall, we think this is a great camera. It's done everything that we've needed it to do and I would recommend it for anyone who's looking for an inexpensive camera that shoots great quality video as long as you can either keep your arm really steady or use a tri-pod.

Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8-awesome little camera !!!!
Reviews.Author: John Gannon
Reviews.Content: I have had the Kodak Zi-8 for 9 months now. I originally bought it because I have twin girls and having a portable video camera available enables me to capture life's fun moments with them. You need to get an external mic for the best sound but Sony has one(ECM-D870P)that I picked up for $5 on ebay. The outdoor video quality approaches my expensive Sony hi-def camcorder, the low lite indoor quality is OK but not the greatest. The ease of putting videos on Youtube, etc is a major plus and I can plug it into my 58" plasma and watch high quality videos immediately. My twin girls love that!!! It is an impressive camera for the price-it will reasonably handle 80-90% of your everyday needs, and you only need to lug out the camcorder for those special ocassions. I find myself posting a new video of my twins on Youtube every two weeks because its so easy!!!

Reviews.Title: Great quality
Reviews.Author: B. Maynard "gamer girl"
Reviews.Content: Great quality. I bought this for my mom for Christmas and she loves it. It's easy to use, but is still fun for someone with a knowledge of technology (aka my mom). Perfect for posting videos on Youtube and other networkings sites. If you would like to see some of the quality, check out my first Youtube video (also, this video was in LOW-LIGHT and still looks incredible!!). The HD version is available at Youtube, just search m00nlightshadows :).[...]

Reviews.Title: Fun little pocket shooter
Reviews.Author: Daniel Blair
Reviews.Content: Tons of fun. Surprising quality in such a tiny package. It takes some serious focus to hold it steady because it is so light and tiny but if it were heavy and huge it would not fit in my pocket. I love that I can plug it directly into my computer with its built in USB. The audio quality is pretty good too. The biggest hassle is buying a memory card but my brother found one on a Christmas sale for me so I didn't have to deal with it.I have taken it hiking, on trampolines, to family reunions, and it has attracted all sorts of attention when people figure out it is not a cell phone. The only peeve I have with the camera is that the lens isn't very wide so you have to take a step back to get your friends into focus. The playsport (zi8's waterproof little brother) has a much more reasonable lens and is waterproof. You need an external cable to upload with that one which I don't always have on me.

Reviews.Title: Nice Little Video Camera
Reviews.Author: J. Singh "Jax"
Reviews.Content: Pros:- Good built quality- Easy to use- Quick turn on time- Fits in BLACKBERRY holster and can be put on belt clipCons- You have to keep hand too sturdy to make a good video (This goes for all pocket video cameras)- Captured sound quality in a party is not that great as not much difference in near and distance voices- No external charger to charge battery externally i.e. so that means if you have 2 batteries you cannot charge while one in use

Reviews.Title: Excellent Choice for Light, Easy Video Capture
Reviews.Author: D. Budd
Reviews.Content: I bought this item as a Christmas present for my wife.  As an aside, she is very, shall we say, "gadget aware," by which I mean she quickly assesses electronic products like this for size, function, ease of use, convenience, and general attractiveness, and is more than willing to turn her nose up at something that doesn't cut it.  Other items have quickly disappeared into the cupboard and never seen again.This camera has been a hit, to say the least.  It is lightweight and sleek, easily fitting into a pocket or carry-along bag.  Its appearance is suitably appealing.  The quality of the video it captures is very, very good, even when expanded to television-sized screens (we've not yet projected it onto a 100-inch screen, but will try it).The camera was used by her to capture our Christmas-day activities, especially our four-year old son opening his presents and playing.  The camera is inconspicuous enough that it did not draw his attention and thus compromise 'candid' shots.  To those of you who have small children, this feature cannot be overstated. It has subsequently been on a trip to Cancun, where it was used to record and share high-quality images of him playing in the sand, in the waves, around the pool, etc.  Since I could not go (working), it was terrific to be able to see each evening videos of the two of them playing.Which gets to the final point- it is quite easy to capture the video and then transfer it to the computer (e.g., youtube, facebook, other social media share sites).  For the non-tech savvy, this is an excellent way by which you can easily, quickly, and conveniently share important moments with friends and family who may be far away. In short, for the relatively low price, it's an excellent buy for people who like to shoot and share video memories, and you need not be Cecil B. DeMille or Alan Turing to use it.

Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8 HD pocket video camera
Reviews.Author: g. goodrich
Reviews.Content: I purchased this pocket video camera in November 2009 shortly before a Mediterranean cruise and after the birth of a grandchild.  I was interested in the HD capability; the shirt pocket portability and  HD quality upon playback. The following are my experiences with this camera to date:HD capability: Although there is a 1080p setting and the picture quality is very good, it is not the quality of the more expensive video cameras on the market today. The 720p, 60 fps may actually create a better video especially if there is action in the video. Many times it is a toss-up as to recording in 1080p or 720p @ 60 fps. The two basic settings on the focal length are good but be aware that moving the telephoto feature during a video is not very smooth and can be a bit annoying on playback on a HDTV. The decision to purchase this camera comes down to the tradeoff between size and portability and having the best HD clarity and full function video. If the video product is mainly for the internet, this camera will likely be fine, if you're archiving young children's activities, doing fast action or low light videos you would be better off spending more money to get a full function video camera. I would also caution someone who is annoyed by less than very high quality video upon playback on HDTV's etc.Firmware updates: I know some reviews have commented on the difficulty with the firmware updating process. I had no trouble at all. I used a Macbook Pro and followed the on-line directions explicitly and everything was fine.Playback is very easy on most TV's especially those with HDMI inputs. The connectivity features of this camera are excellent and playback directly from the camera to an HDTV are simple, fast and of high quality. The enclosed cable from the camera to an HDMI input is all that is required. The flip-out USB connector is very good. The camera also has an intuitive video indexing feature which makes playbacks of many different video clips relatively easy.Portability: this camera is truly shirt pocket portable and I can be carrying this camera more often and have it on me for unanticipated opportunities for a short video clip. This size of camera is not very obtrusive when recording. One of my peeves is people on trips running around with large video camera's recording everything in sight. This camera allows for short, discreet video captures.I am very satisfied with this camera and rated it quite high. It is important to understand this camera's features, capabilities, and limitations and compare that to the applications and features you value most. Thinking this through will produce the best buying decision.

Reviews.Title: Hell of a device - Blows all others out of the water
Reviews.Author: Zachary D. Saltman
Reviews.Content: I just got this from bestbuy (they gave me 50% off b/c the box had been opened but the camcorder never used - sick deal).I was looking at all the pocket HD camcorders, and had decided the Kodak Zi8 was too expensive. Thank god I found this deal, because this thing is worth every damn penny, even paying the full retail price.I'm in Colorado skiing right now, and took the Zi8 up on the mountain. I used picture mode, as well as the 720p 60fps (sport) mode for action ski videos. I haven't gotten home yet to upload to my computer, but the pictures and videos look pristine on the camcorder itself (which has a great quality and size screen). The 720p 60fps HD video didn't miss a thing. Flawlessly smooth with video quality so high that I can't even imagine what the 1080p would look like. I was holding it filming as I skied through dense trees, so it handled both fast action motion and low-light conditions. Basically, both the picture and video quality was great on the mountain, even when the visability and lighting was bad. I almost forgot, even the digital zoom was way better than I'd expect. This thing just blew me away.I'll break down why this thing is by far the most superior pocket HD camcorder:1. Quality. nothing can touch this thing in that department, unless you go up to bigger HD camcorders obviously.2. Takes Pictures. I don't have a digital camera, so I wanted a pocket HD camcorder that takes good quality stills. The ever-so-popular Flip doesn't do stills, and the other ones that do don't do them well from what I hear.3. Build/Design. Well constructed, sleek, very easy to use, beautiful large screen for reviewing your stills and videos. Having physical buttons instead of "touch" buttons is often overlooked. You always know what you're pressing, and you don't ever accidentally mess up your videos, because you don't have to worry about those annoying "touch" buttons.4. accessories. comes with ALL the cords and TV cables you'd need (for HD and SD TVs), as well as a nice leather wrist-strap, which I loved b/c it made sure I didn't drop it into the snow.Only criticisms (minor as they are):1. a little big, but not bad. Kind of like the size of a Blackberry, maybe a tad bigger. Can't be greedy though, this thing films 1080p full HD, and 60fps 720p HD. It's tiny when you consider that fact.2. software. CORRECTION: I initially said the Arcsoft MediaImpression software didn't run well, but it works fine. It's quite adequate, and from the reviews of other comparable devices, it seems superior.3. price. It's pricey, but man is it worth it. Especially when the Flip is similarly priced.This is my favorite gadget in awhile. The pros WAAAAY outweigh the cons (which are nearly non-existent). If you're looking for an HD pocket camcorder and want media and build quality, look no further. This is for you.

Reviews.Title: Issues with camcorder...returned it
Reviews.Author: J. Keil
Reviews.Content: Got the camcorder as a Christmas gift. Have some issues with it that I feel I need to put out there as I returned it.First, it would be a great camcorder if not for the faults. But the faults I found outweigh the features. Here are the issues I ran into:-Received my camcorder with firmware 1.06 that was supposed to fix old issues, but only brought new ones.-When recording indoors in low light, blue line appears across recordings...very frustrating and makes recording indoors a pain.-When zooming in indoors, after zooming in about halfway the image goes dark, I mean really dark. When zoomed back out it lightens up again, but whats the point of having zoom if it goes dark every time you zoom in?-Also, the thin streaks....this is an issue people have had. While recording the screen still shows the thin streaks, although they don't appear in the video. But really, its pretty annoying while filming.I rated it a two because it could be very good in theory...but the performance isn't up to snuff. I am going to get the creative vado HD. Its 60 dollars less, and from what I have read is a very solid option.Thanks

Reviews.Title: Excellent mini-camcorder
Reviews.Author: A.P
Reviews.Content: I've had several digital camcorders in the past decade (mostly using miniDV format tapes), and was looking to move to something I would actually carry around and use.  I was also tired of the cumbersome transfer process that the miniDV devices made you go through.  So I was looking at a Flip until this came out.  I chose this one because I thought it would be neat to have still photo capabilities as well.  I've had it for a few months so far, and my impressions are as follows:1) The video quality is excellent and has surpassed my expectations.  The video can by shaky sometimes, but that's generally my fault and probably not surprising since I'm usually running after my children, but both in low light and outdoor situations, the image quality is usually quite sharp.  I would have liked an optical zoom, but it's important to remember that such things are against the spirit of these kind of cameras.2) The ease of use in terms of startup, recording, playback, and data transfer are all that I hoped for.  I also like the ease of hooking up to a TV to watch videos quickly.3) The still photo capabilities are spartan, so you should not expect to replace your regular still camera with this.  The shots are probably okay for facebook-quality pics,  but nothing beyond that.  It is 5MP, but the shutterspeed is slow, there is no flash, and no control over any of the parameters.In summary, it's a great mini-camcorder and I've been very happy with it so far.  Probably it's greatest feature is that it's small enough to actually take with you most places, and you will therefore get footage you wouldn't have gotten with your high-quality but bulky camcorder that you left at home.  I give it a solid 4 stars and recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8 - Bob's Review
Reviews.Author: Knives Town "- An online knife store"
Reviews.Content: I love shooting video but have never been fond of carrying around a camcorder which requires a camera bag on my shoulder or looking like an idiot with it around my neck. I had my eye on the Flip cameras since they came out and when I read other reviews that the Zi8 was supposed to be even better and slimmer too, I took the plunge. I am glad I did as I have been enjoying the new found video freedom this little unit provides and it has reignited all that I originally found so compelling about shooting video.The resolution is great! No one can lay a legitimate complaint against that. Some have complained about a whine in the mic or jerky zoom. I never had the mic problem, but yes on the zoom issue. My unit shipped with 1.03 software and the Koday website has already upgraded to 1.06. I downloaded that firmware and now the zoom is smooth as silk and never any whine in the mic. I put a 16GB class 6 Centon card in it and I get a good 2hrs on 720/60fps.I give high marks to this unit all around. I have not really found the EIS even necessary. Anyone who is experienced at shooting video knows SLOW movement is required whatever camera you are using unless you want to get nauseous watching your vids. I had already developed a slow, steady hand, so I just leave the EIS off. All the controls on the camera are very intuitive and the Arcsoft software on board is good.If I had to request an improvement on the next gen, I would ask for two things. First, I would like a better built in mic. Yes, it is great that you can plug in an external, but the purpose of owning this unit is to have a portable camera in your pocket you can pull out and have ready in an instant. If I have to do the external mic thing, then I am getting closer to might as well use the bulky old Handycam unit. I don't want a two piece camera, just one small hand-held that picks up good quality sound please.  The other item I might like to see would be better white balance handling. The unit will sometimes struggle with white balance and flare during the videos for no apparent reason.Other than that, I think it is fantastic and I do consider these issues nit picking, especially at a $150 price point. I can give a hands down recommendation for this unit.  It is a solid performer and delivers a lot of value for the $$ and size.

Reviews.Title: Firmware download problems for the Zi8
Reviews.Author: C. Rutter-Armes
Reviews.Content: I knew in advance that the Zi8 had a problem with a whinning sound on playback but also knew from an Amazon review that this could be fixed with a firmware download and than the problem would be solved. I purchased 2 cameras for Christmas presents and figured I would download the new firmware before giving the gifts..Well good luck with that. We tried several times on our own but finally called Kodak for help. seems you can download to the card but the camera cannot get the info once the card is placed in the camera.A problem that some of the cameras are having. I was given 2 options. One send the cameras to them to download the firmware which will take 10 to 12 business days once they get them, oh and I have to pay shipping, or send them back for to where they where purchased and get two new cameras and hope they can get the download. Since I need these for Christmas I guess I have to go thru the aggrivation of getting new cameras.  Just want to let everyone know that you too may run into this problem. The Camera is great otherwise.

Reviews.Title: Simple, Effective, Affordable - Perfect if on a budget!
Reviews.Author: melhsap "lcmshsadmin"
Reviews.Content: Pros: Cost, Quality of Video (True 1080p), Simple Controls, Variety of Settings for Video Format, 3.5mm Exterior Mic Input Jack - HDMI cord included!Cons: Doesn't ship with a SDHC Memory CardSummary: I bought this video camera to take family videos of piano recitals, basketball games, etc. to save for posterity, to post for the grandparents to watch, and other typical uses...just the sort of niche in the market it is supposed to fill. The 1080p video is crisp, indoors or out, and putting it on 720p/60fps for action video like the directions tell you to do, makes a huge difference. Yes, it isn't quite what it could be in low light, but it is not as bad as some reviews make it seem - at least not in my opinion. Besides, it not really designed to be a serious movie maker.While the price isn't bad, I got mine for $149 with free shipping, you will have to invest a little more to really get the most from it. I bought a 32gb SDHC card for $80, an extra battery for $10 (look around on the internet), an external stereo mic (Mine - Sony ECM-DS70P Electret Condenser Stereo Microphone - works great) for $24, and I added a $10 case from Wally World. Total (including camera) - $273ish, but you may be able to do better THE EXTRAS WERE WORTH EVERY PENNY! I get great video, great stereo sound, and have plenty of power.I am sure something better will come along soon. I've long since accepted that as a fact of modern technology, but for the price and my needs, I'm quite satisfied.Oh yeah, install the latest 1.06 firmware upgrade, it solves the sound problem that some people are whining about (pun intended)!

Reviews.Title: Awesome pocket camcorder.  Best bang for the buck
Reviews.Author: Dave Turner
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased the Zi8 from a local store and couldn't be any happier with it.  When I first thought about buying a pocket camcorder, I immediately thought about the Flip UltraHD because a friend has one.  While researching that, I came across the Zi8 and am extremely glad I did.  The best review of both that I've found is on the the HighTechDad website.There's not much more that I can add that hasn't already been said in the other 5 star reviews.  This thing is amazing!  Kodak updated their firmware (current version 1.06) in November and that addressed all of the issues discussed in the other reviews.  You need to take that into consideration when reading the older reviews.  When my camera arrived, it had version 1.03 and I noticed many of the issues that others have discussed.  After updating, everything was fine.Bottom line, I'd highly recommend the Zi8 to everyone but be sure to update the firmware immediately.Update (12/5/09) - I bought the Lowepro Ridge 30 case and it's a perfect fit.

Reviews.Title: perfect for quick moments and funny clips
Reviews.Author: O. Muammar "DA BEARS"
Reviews.Content: This thing is great and simple to use. It is better then anything out their under 200 dollars or in its class. People do complain about zoom not being great or mic having issues these are from a firmware update, once the update is done it works great. Has alota cool options like EIS, face recognition, and mic sensitivity settings. EIS isnt that great but its not good on any pocket camera, so you cant hold it against the zi8. Also has macro view and can make things very clear if done right. Has 720 at 60fps which no other pocket cam has let alone cameras that cost 500 dollars. Its a great value and gets the job done. If you want to get an idea of what the recording is like look it up on youtube. Their are many comparison videos to other pocket cams. this does come out being slightly better then most. battery life is not good so keep that in mind and you do need to get a sd card when you buy it. Make sure the SD card is class 6 or higher to transfer information faster resulting in better quality overall.

Reviews.Title: Awesome HD camera on a budget!
Reviews.Author: William R. Wood
Reviews.Content: I've had my Kodak Zi8 for couple weeks and love it, very portable and lightweight!  I carry it in my back pocket and feels like my iphone.  I would recommend upgrading the firmware as soon as you get it to fix the mic whining noise and improved low light videos.  You can see one of my night shoots in Warm Springs, Ga this past weekend on youtube by searching warm springs and zi8.  I paid $149 on amazon 3 weeks ago, but see it's gone back up to $176 today, still worth it! Hope this helps

Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8 Pocket Video Camera
Reviews.Author: Gary S. Shogren "Digitalman"
Reviews.Content: The Kodak Zi8 Pocket Video Camera is very easy to use and is so small and lightweight you can take it with you anywhere. The picture quality is fine and with the optional memory card you can take plenty of videos. Editing and uploading are breeze with the built in software. For the price, you can't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: A Sweet Little Camera--But Buy A Memory Stick!
Reviews.Author: Leslie
Reviews.Content: I wanted a very portable, easy-to-use, basic camera for family use, and this fits the bill perfectly. Picture quality is very good (high density is available) and focus is fine. I like the fact that you can switch from "landscape" mode (most uses -- a meter or more away) to "macro" mode (for ultra close-ups just inches away). My biggest concern was how my less-than-steady hand would affect jumpiness, but it's no worry at all.What I failed to recognize when I bought the camera was that it really can't be used without a memory card; internal memory gives you maybe 20 seconds of video at the lowest resolution. Memory cards are anywhere from off-brand cheap to high-end expensive. After reading reviews, I decided on the moderately priced Kodak brand and went for the 8 MB card ($39.95 + free shipping at HSN as of Nov 09). You'll also want to buy a case, since the lens has no cap.The biggest disappointment is the zoom (digital not optical), which is very jumpy. I've read online that Kodak has a firmware update that you can download to resolve this problem, however. Another thing to consider: apparently XP has a problem reading the 8 MB memory card. But there's a download on the Microsoft site to fix this (KB934428). I haven't done either of these yet, but plan to do so.

Reviews.Title: Just one knock on an otherwise great pocket camcorder
Reviews.Author: Ricardo Lewis "Rick"
Reviews.Content: This is a truly nice piece of technology save for the jittery zoom and spotty audio problems (which the 1.06 firmware upgrade eventually fixed). The Kodak Zi8 is far superior than the Sony WebbieHD in low light situations, and the picture quality is excellent for the price. The external microphone input was a major plus in my decision to purchase this camcorder. The one knock that I have is that the 1.06 firmware update from Kodak substantially DECREASED the recording time on my 8GB and 16GB memory cards. The recording time, at 720p, on the 8GB SDHC card went from 02:27:00 down to 01:18:00, losing more than one hour of recording time. I purchased a new 16GB SDHC card and it's recording time is about what the original 8GB card's time was - BUMMER! Reformatting the card did not help. I've contacted Kodak and hope that they come out with a firmware fix that will give me my money's worth on these expensive memory cards. Otherwise, it a nice little camcorder for the price.

Reviews.Title: Addicted to Zi8
Reviews.Author: iBeatz
Reviews.Content: I've never done a review but I was compelled to write one this time since I had been interested in buying a pocket cam. I did a ton of research on just about every single pocket cam out there. Watched countless of YouTube videos from most of the cameras out in the market and finally decided to buy the ZI8. So it's been a week and I absolutely love this camera. Just keep in mind that this will have limits because it is a pocket cam, so you have to purchase it with realistic expectations. When I got it, it did have the high pitch problem but I was not worried since I had already read about the problem, it was fixed right away with the firmware upgrade.The main reason I bought the Zi8 was for portability (of course), I'm a musician and I've always wanted to be able to shoot video of artists I work with, live shows, music conferences etc. And thus far, it has been perfect - I walk into a club with my cam in my pocket and  film a performance pretty much under the radar, no one cares or even notices.I would like to add that I bought the SONY ECM-DS70P stereo MIC and it's a really good little mic for the ZI8. If you need stereo like I do (for music) it's worth it and probably will make your ZI8's audio quality better than any other pocket cam out there. I'm sure pocket cams will continue to improve, but I'm having a lot of fun with this one so far.

Reviews.Title: A Great Pocket Video Camera
Reviews.Author: C. Martin
Reviews.Content: Kodak has done a great job with the ZI8.  I am not seeing any of the issues posted here.  I have a 'regular' HD camcorder by Canon (HG10) and this one makes me want to leave the Canon at home many times due to its size and very good video quality.I have not had any of the issues reported here so far.  The sound from it is good.  Both my wife and I were surprised how good it is after reading all the negative comments about the sound.  I also have not seen any issues with lines at any of the resolutions.  The image is pretty much what you see is what you get in good light.  In dim light, my Canon is better.The firmware is simple to upgrade - took me about 3 minutes total.  Not sure why everyone is having issues with this...I have a regular Flip Ultra camcorder non HD and this is a HUGE step up from that.  The video quality is noticeably better.Highly recommended...

Reviews.Title: Kodak Zi8 vs Flip Ultra HD ver 2
Reviews.Author: Pam
Reviews.Content: I have a Kodak Zi8 using a Lithium battery and a Flip Ultra HD version 2 which uses two AA batteries.  The Flip comes with 2 hours recording time, the Kodak comes with enough memory for a few pictures but you can buy up to a 32 gb memory cards which supposedly holds up to 10 hours with at 720p 30 fps.But it doesn't help much since the Kodak at 720p at 30 fps ran out of battery after just over 1.5 hours of continuous shooting on a tripod. Solution: buy multiple batteries and swap them out. Other reviews said to turn off the autoshake to improve the battery.The picture quality and sound are not as good as my Flip Ultra. The Kodak does have a macro mode which my Flip doesn't, so you can get in close to read print with it, better than the Flip. I was holding both cameras side by side about 3 ft away - the Flip is sharper and the sound is better. The Flip does a better job autofocusing, keeping everything sharp, while the Kodak you have to make sure everything is in the same plane otherwise part of the picture is out of focus. The advantage of Kodak is that you can add an external microphone which should make the sound quality better than my Flip.I also bought a second Kodak at the same time I bought the first one and it would zoom in, but wouldn't zoom out unless I turned the camera off - defective.  So I'm not so sure about Kodak quality.  The ease of use of my Flip is better, but the Kodak is thinner, looks cooler, and has a fun joy stick.  But in the beginning I had to read the manual to figure out how to play back video, while the Flip has a play button which is easy to figure out.The display on the Kodak, although bigger, is not sharp.  My Flip display is really amazing quality, the same as I would get on my PC, just smaller.  After downloading the videos.  The Kodak looks like it is made for wide screen, and my Flip seems like it is made more for a regular monitor.  I expected them to be the same size but they are not.  The colors on both are good, but different.  The sharpness and autofocus quality on the Flip surpasses the Kodak.I'm keeping both and will use both, the Kodak with a microphone and for closeups.  My Flip for everything else.Flip Ultra Video Camera - White, 4 GB, 2 Hours (2nd Generation) OLD MODELI wish I could find a videocamera that is the best of both of these.

Reviews.Title: Poor Prooduct, Bad Customer Service
Reviews.Author: Bob A
Reviews.Content: This camera disguises itself as a quality camera but it actually a very poor quality product.The audio playback is so low that it is almost impossible to hear. The 4x zoom is digital only and the picture becomes grainy as soon as you use it. Individual pictures are not as good as those taken with a low cost digital camera.  Our Droid X cell phone from Verizon is a much better camera.We purchased this camera about 14 months ago and only used it a couple of times.  It was kept home put away.  We went on vacation last month and decided to use it. The first time we tried it wouldn't focus or zoom,  We removed and reinstalled the battery but it didn't help.I contacted Kodak Customer Service via chat but they did not have any solution to help us with the defective camera.  The cost to send it in for repair was as much as I could buy one for.  They do not offer any exchange for a price.  They offered a 15% discount off another Kodak product if I purchased it from them.  That is a joke.  My camera is basically new and it is defective.  A company that cares about their customers, a quality company, would offer an acceptable soultion.  The customer service rep actually said "I understand your problem but there is nothing I can do".  What this means is that Kodak doesn't care about a customer after the sale. I paid $186.00 for this camera.  This is a complete loss.  I have never had any quality use from it.  Do not buy a Kodak Zi8 and beware of Kodak Customer Service

Reviews.Title: Not sure what all the griping is about.
Reviews.Author: G. Chadwell "Pempfist71"
Reviews.Content: Why gripe? You get what you pay for. It's up to you as consumers to thoroughly research a product before you click BUY.This camera does what its supposed to do, and as advertised, if you want more features, then you will pay more. I knew exactly what I was getting into when I purchased this camera, and it works flawlessly for my use. The price is fantastic also.

Reviews.Title: Great, fun camera.  BUT, not a replacement for digital camera.
Reviews.Author: LE "LE"
Reviews.Content: This is a great, fun, and cool pocket camcorder.  But, it's not a replacement for your regular camcorder or digital camera.The video recording is high quality and easy to use and the still pictures are decent as long as you are not in low light.This is basically a youtube camera.  Don't expect professional results from a pocket camera, and you'll be happy.Unfortunately, I had to return it.  I was trying to replace a digital camera that was dropped, but this camera does not have a built-in flash.This made it useless for me, b/c sometimes I need to take pictures of houses where there is no electricity(and no lights).  I don't need it to be super high quality, but I do need a flash.I'll definitely buy the next model if they add a light/flash.

Reviews.Title: New Firmware 1.06
Reviews.Author: Thomas Galfano "FamilyGuy"
Reviews.Content: I have already posted a review indicating I really liked the camera considering the 'cost' and what we are using it for, which is casual video capture. I was not expecting video of a prosumer camera and since there were low light issues with the Canon and Sony models we decided to get teh Zi8 until CES 2010 and we can look at some new models from the big 2.I thought the worst thing about the camera was the somewhat weak audio capture of the built in mic (hey- it still works fine, just leaves a little to be desired and the external mic worked great with a basic Sony stereo mic) and the zoom was a bit jerky- like it was too fast and did not have slow start.Low light was just OK with a mix of success- but I was just happy to get something usable. Normal might condition was fine- we captured Halloween with the kids and we are very happy with it.But now the new firmware looks to address this (below)- I am going to update my camera this evening and will take it for a test drive in the next couple of days and repost again.Anyone else that did the update can update their review.[...]KODAK Zi8 Pocket Video Camera Firmware 1.06 November-2009 64 megabytes  Cable/DSL: 4-11 minutesDial-up: 201 minutesThis firmware version provides WINDOWS 7 compatibility and improves the following features: Audio recording and playback; Digital Zoom; User Interface; Video quality in low-light conditions.

Reviews.Title: Great for the money!
Reviews.Author: E. Myers "BigDawg"
Reviews.Content: Pros:-  Picture quality for the money is outstanding-  Very simple to use-  Like the options of Standard Definition (uses less memory), 720p @ 60 fps (for sports), and 1080p (for those special mements)-  External microphone jack is big plus-  Comes with HDMI cable for playback on HDTV-  Uses replaceable SD cards so you're not stuck with the built-in memoryCons:-  Battery life is short and the battery is Kodak specific so can't just buy some cheaper generic AAA replacements-  The sound quality is okay (not any worse than any of our old camcorders).  I ordered an external mic, but has not arrived yet.Other Thoughts:Got it for my wife who is "technically challenged". She LOVES it. I do too. Last Christmas I got her a Canon FS100 which was our first flash based camcorder. It was nice, but frankly I was a little disappointed in the picture quality especially when played back on an HDTV. It was stolen a few months ago, so my wife has been bugging me for a new one ever since. I decided I wanted to go HD this time. I started researching and most of the regular HD camcorders are over five hundred dollars which I really did not want to spend. I decided to look at the Flip UltraHD since it was under two hundred dollars.  I paid almost three hundred for the Canon FS100, so I was skeptical of these Point & Share HD camcorders for under two hundred. The Flip seemed like a decent option, but I didn't like the fact that it didn't take SD cards. The last thing I want is to be taping my son's birthday and then run out of space with no option to add a new SD card. Then I stumbled on to this Kodak Zi8 and I am soooo glad! I like it better than the FS100 which is more expensive.  Highly recommend!Other Note:I don't use the bundled software.  The movies are .mov which is Apple's format that uses Quicktime.  Since I use iTunes, I already had Quicktime on my computer so no problems for playback.  For importing the videos on to the computer, I use Picasa (Google's free picture managing software) which does video now too.  It works great and helps me organize all the videos the same way I do my photos.  Also, Picasa has a button that takes a still photo from the movie.  I LOVE this option because I don't feel like I need to take my point & shoot camera AND my camcorder.  I just use the camcorder and it is like having 30 pictures per second.  The only thing I need the point & shoot camera for is those really low light situations that require a flash.

Reviews.Title: Superb entry level camcorder
Reviews.Author: Keir Darcey
Reviews.Content: I just received this today and uploaded the 1.03 firmware. The famous high pitched whine from 1.01 is gone. The firmware update solved the microphone issue completely.Kodak put out a good product. Unfortunately, the 1080p mode is far too jittery with motion. Even when using a tripod during daylight, it just doesn't seem usable. 720p at 60 fps is perfectly acceptable for my home movies, though.

Reviews.Title: Best in it's class
Reviews.Author: kylehase
Reviews.Content: Pros:-The zi8 is significantly slimmer than the Flip HD making it much more pocketable.-The screen is larger and much clearer than the Flip as well.-The anti-shake feature is decent but I've noticed that it works best for vertical shaking as opposed to pan and tilt shaking.-The removable media and battery are certainly welcome features as is the external mic port.Cons:-I haven't yet heard any of that high-pitch sound others are complaining about.-This device suffers the dreaded "jello effect".  This is less noticeable in 60fps mode.-The lens is not wide enough IMO and 1080p mode zooms even closer for some reason.-Battery life was less than 1hr at 720p/30fps and you can't use a PC to charge the device even though it comes with a USB charger cable.  (There's a 'no PC' label on the cord presumably because of insufficient current.)-Zooming is not smooth.-White balance is not perfect and exposure metering is slow to adjust to changes in lighting.

Reviews.Title: They lied, tech support sucks, I'm getting my money back
Reviews.Author: Detroit Mike
Reviews.Content: I own a Flip Video and thought that this one looked much better--image stability, 1080p, still shots--so I ordered before its September 1st release and actually received it on Friday, August 28th.  I charged it, I took a short video, and then attached it to my Windows Vista Home Premium PC.  The device driver was installed okay but the subsequent installation of ArcSoft MediaImpression software did not occur.  This lead to four tech contacts:1. Kodak via online chat.  I explained that the software did not install.  She took my serial number.  She then told me that I would have to contact ArcSoft about the software since Kodak didn't have it.  This was Saturday and ArcSoft is open Monday through Friday.  In the meantime, I went to the ArcSoft site and (a) there was nothing there specifically for Kodak and (b) the free version of MediaImpression that was available only did photos, not movies.2. ArcSoft via telephone.  I told the fellow what the Kodak support person had told me.  He informed me that I would have to get the software from Kodak--they didn't have it.3. Kodak via online chat immediately after the ArcSoft phone call.  I gave the new tech support guy the case number of my previous call.  He eventually told me to download and install EasyShare software, a free Kodak software package.  I was using Firefox and could not get the online installation to work, so I confirmed with him that I was to download and install EasyShare, restart my machine, then once again attach the Zi8 for the ArcSoft installation.  I closed Firefox and opened IE.  I had to restart my machine, close everything, and then run the Cygwin installation of EasyShare.  I never received any indication that the installation was successful and, after yet another restart, could not find EasyShare on my machine.4. Kodak via online chat again.  The last tech support person read over the notes from the previous sessions and told me that I would have to get the software from ArcSoft.  I explained to him that ArcSoft told me to get it from Kodak and now Kodak was once again telling me to get it from ArcSoft and that that situation would not work.  He then said that I could use the MediaImpression CD that came with the camera to do the installation.  I told him that I did not receive any CD in the box and, in an attempt to actually get to the point where I was willing to keep the camera even with the terrible tech support I was receiving, asked him to send me the CD that I did not get.  He told me to go to the ArcSoft site and download the software--you know, the program that does pictures but not movies.So, I got a return label from Amazon and will ship it back for a refund tomorrow.  I also will NEVER EVER buy anything from Kodak EVER AGAIN.

Reviews.Title: Mediocre - not worth more than $99
Reviews.Author: Christoph B. Lemmonds "Kit Lemmonds"
Reviews.Content: The good:1) 720p 60fps is the best shooting mode and is tolerable in bright light2) unit fits in pocket if you could protect the lens somehow3) decent battery life4) hdmi5) offers many options (but none are implemented well)The bad:1) inexcusably horrible software package meant to bilk customers out of more money2) glitchy performance - especially for facial detection3) compression leaves numerous artifacts (cross-hatches) in video (should have option of shooting uncompressed)4) no lens cover and this unit attracts lint like a magnet5) poor lens choice for personal shooting6) micro mode is a good idea, but poorly implemented7) saves to .mov files8) do not even think about shooting in anything but full, bright light.9) wonky wiggle-stick button for most functions10) still camera is uselessThe specs look nice for this camera - four shooting modes (1080p, 720p-60fps, 720p-30fps, wvga), panorama and micro modes, facial detection, electronic image stabilization, but none of these options are implemented particularly well.  I would have preferred a single shooting mode as long as it offered sharp images in average light.  And why include a still camera feature if the resulting images are worse than cell phone pictures from years ago?  It seems like Kodak was more concerned with the spec sheet than performance.  Perhaps they were wanting to compete with the flip cameras.  Ironically, the mediocre performance from the Zi8 positions it closer to the $99 aiptec hd cams you buy at Walgreens.HD claims have to be taken with a grain of salt for these little cameras.  They may record in HD, but if the sensor can only detect blurry, chunky images than you're just recording every detail of a bad image.  For the money, you would probably be better off with standard definition from a better sensor.The lens choice for the Zi8 is puzzling.  The depth of focus makes no sense for personal shooting.  They were nice enough to include panorama & micro modes - but the depth of focus on micro is 5 inches, so you're camera is right in someone's face and you'll only catch their eyes and part of a nose.  Panorama makes more sense, but everything close is blurred.  If you're shooting in anything less than full sunlight (ie - anywhere indoors), everything is kinda blurred anyway.  Zoom is absolutely useless and I'm not sure why they even bothered; if something cannot be implemented well, it shouldn't be implemented at all.The Zi8's worst limitation is that it's crippled by a horrible software package and file format.  I chose this camera because it stores video to SDHC which my televisions read.  All of my dvd players play divX video, so I planned to convert all files to divX disks for ultra-long playback.  Unfortunately - when I started trying to work with the files this camera produces I found that the device was hobbled to ArcSoft MediaImpression software.  You'd think this software would allow you to convert your videos - and it kinda does...to other .mov resolutions.  To remedy this - I went to the arcsoft site to download the necessary codecs and quickly found that this was one of those "bait and switch" software houses that only exists because they make exclusivity agreements with hardware makers.  The software itself cannot compete with other software and only exists because the hardware buyer has no choice.  When you go to their site you're bombarded with offers to "upgrade" your software for a measly $60 charge (almost half the cost of the camera).  Thinking that they still might have codecs, I registered and they sent me a confirmation email. But the confirmation link was bad and I had to manually set it to a valid address.  Then - the support form bombed on another error!  Did the same people who coded the site code the horrible software?  It sure seems like it.Keeping everything in perspective - the Zi8 is not a horrible camera for $150, but it's not particularly good either.  The camera's mediocre performance makes it better situated for a $99 price point.  I've learned a valuable lesson about specs vs performance.  I'm considering returning the Zi8 for a camera with a better lens & sensor - even if it's standard definition, and I may avoid Kodak products in the future.  Any hardware maker that makes these greedy Faustian bargains with inferior software houses to try and bleed more money from their customers does not deserve customers at all.  I will definitely never buy another product bundled with ArcSoft garbage-ware.

Reviews.Title: Almost perfect...
Reviews.Author: B. A Reichle
Reviews.Content: Wow. This thing is the bee's knees. I have been holding off buying a "Flip" cam since my old DSC-T500 sony digital camera filmed such great HD videos I had no need..Now Kodak (hmm) just released their Zi8 and I kept hearing good things about it, and its also Sold Out almost everywhere. I got my hands on one, tested it out, and JESUS! This camera rules!! A perfect pocket camera with stunning video quality, A PLUG FOR MICROPHONE INPUTS (TAKE THAT FLIP!), hdmi, image stabilization, face detection, and 1080P. Yes thats right.. 1080P for under $200 in your pocket.It has its flaws, nothing can be perfect right? The zoom is jerky (not a big deal but seriously stupid) and the red light in the front cant be turned off when recording (not yet, future firmware update maybe?)In the category of cheap pocket cams, you cant beat this..
